head.title: Getting Tan in a Real-World Environment

hedline.hl1: Getting Tan in a Real-World Environment

block.p: Re "Don't Bother Me: I'm Catching Some Rays" (Week in Review, July 2), on sunbathing:
Re "Don't Bother Me: I'm Catching Some Rays" (Week in Review, July 2), on sunbathing:

Health concerns about ultraviolet radiation have been escalating as a result of the ever-increasing hole in the atmospheric ozone layer, the earth's protective shield from UV radiation. Melanoma is still on the rise, despite a decrease in the popularity of sunbathing.
The Antarctic and Arctic have been reported to have 70 percent and 30 percent, respectively, less than normal levels of ozone.
The issue is not so much of fashion or trend, but the disastrous consequences of altering the global life support system of the atmosphere in which we live.

The Montreal Protocol, the international agreement to curb and eventually stop the production of ozone-depleting chlorofluorocarbons, is not itself without holes. China's booming electronic industry relies heavily on CFC's, and China has refused to sign or comply. In our own country the issue is enforcement.
An increased awareness of the connection between our daily living habits and the larger system must be recognized. GAIL W. WITTWER New York, July 2, 1995
